questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a long-standing history of "feeling tensed" along with an upset stomach, diarrhea, and heartburn. She mentions that her family members also experience similar symptoms. Which of the following symptoms is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tingling at extremities is a common somatic symptom in generalized anxiety disorder due to hyperventilation and autonomic arousal.

  • The clinical features described-chronic tension, gastrointestinal complaints like diarrhea and heartburn, and family history-are characteristic of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD).
  • In GAD, prolonged stress leads to autonomic hyperactivity, resulting in symptoms such as tingling or numbness in extremities, muscle tension, restlessness, and fatigue.
  • These somatic complaints often lead to repeated medical evaluations before a psychiatric diagnosis is made.
  • Hyperventilation and heightened sympathetic activity are commonly responsible for these paresthesias in anxiety disorders.

Explanation of other options:

Neologisms (Option A): Typically seen in schizophrenia, where patients create new, nonsensical words; not a feature of anxiety disorders.

Hallucinations (Option C): Involve false sensory perceptions without external stimuli, usually associated with psychotic disorders.

Idea of reference (Option D): A psychotic symptom where neutral events are perceived as having personal significance-commonly seen in schizophrenia and paranoid states, not in GAD.

questions.text: Which drug is commonly used in the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used for maintenance therapy in opioid dependence due to its ability to reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms.

  • Buprenorphine is widely used during the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal as part of Opioid Substitution Therapy (OST).
  • It is a partial opioid agonist with a ceiling effect, which lowers the risk of overdose while effectively reducing withdrawal symptoms and cravings.
  • It is usually administered sublingually and can also be combined with naloxone to prevent misuse.
  • Buprenorphine is effective in stabilizing opioid-dependent patients and allowing them to maintain functional lives while gradually tapering off opioids.
  • Other agents used in OST include methadone (a full opioid agonist) and naltrexone (an antagonist).
  • However, buprenorphine is preferred for maintenance due to its safety profile and reduced abuse potential.

Explanation of other options:

Disulfiram (Option B): Used as an aversive agent in alcohol dependence, not effective in opioid withdrawal management.

Butorphanol (Option C): A mixed opioid agonist-antagonist used mainly for pain relief, not approved for maintenance therapy in opioid use disorder.

Clonidine (Option D): An alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to alleviate acute withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, tremor, and sweating, but not effective as a long-term maintenance drug.

questions.text: A man experiences sexual arousal from wearing female undergarments and high heels during sexual activity with women, but he is not attracted to men. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Transvestic Fetishism involves sexual arousal from wearing clothing of the opposite sex without a desire to change one's gender identity.

  • Transvestic Fetishism is classified under paraphilic disorders and is defined as sexual arousal obtained from cross-dressing, i.e., wearing clothes of the opposite sex.
  • It commonly occurs in heterosexual men, as in this case, where the man is not attracted to men but gets aroused by wearing female undergarments and high heels.
  • Importantly, there is no desire to transition genders, which distinguishes it from Gender Dysphoria.
  • The presence of this behavior in a sexual context, and not as a reflection of gender identity, confirms the diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism.

Explanation of other options:

Gender Dysphoria (Option A): Involves psychological distress due to a mismatch between one's assigned gender at birth and experienced gender identity-not about sexual arousal from cross-dressing.

Hermaphroditism (Option C): Refers to an intersex condition involving both male and female genital characteristics; it is a biological disorder, not a psychiatric or behavioral one.

Gay Identity Disorder (Option D): Not a valid diagnostic term in current medical or psychiatric classifications. Moreover, the man is not attracted to men, so this is inapplicable.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used to manage ADHD?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that has been used off-label in the management of ADHD, especially when stimulants are not appropriate.

  • Reboxetine is a non-stimulant antidepressant belonging to the selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) class.
  • It works by inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, thereby increasing its levels in the synaptic cleft.
  • While not first-line for ADHD, reboxetine is occasionally used off-label when stimulant medications (e.g., methylphenidate or amphetamines) are contraindicated-such as in patients with:
    • History of substance abuse
    • Tics or Tourette's syndrome
    • Cardiovascular concerns
  • It may help improve attention and focus through enhanced noradrenergic signaling in the prefrontal cortex.

Explanation of other options:

Modafinil (Option A): A wakefulness-promoting agent used primarily for narcolepsy, obstructive sleep apnea, and shift-work sleep disorder. Though sometimes used off-label in ADHD, it is not an NRI.

Guanfacine (Option C): An alpha-2A adrenergic receptor agonist, used in ADHD treatment, particularly for hyperactivity and impulsivity, but not an NRI.

Methylphenidate (Option D): A CNS stimulant that blocks reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine, but is not selective for norepinephrine, and thus not classified as a selective NRI.

questions.text: A mother brings her daughter to the emergency room after she ingested an unknown substance. The child presents with hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and mydriasis. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cocaine causes sympathomimetic toxidrome, characterized by hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and mydriasis due to increased catecholamine levels.

  • Cocaine is a powerful CNS stimulant derived from the Erythroxylum coca plant.
  • It is commonly abused for its euphoric and energizing effects.
    • Mechanism of Action:
      • Cocaine blocks the reuptake of:
      • Norepinephrine (NE)
      • Dopamine (DA)
      • Serotonin (5-HT)
    • This leads to increased synaptic concentrations of these neurotransmitters, especially norepinephrine, resulting in sympathomimetic stimulation.
  • Clinical Features of Cocaine Toxicity:
    • Hypertension
    • Tachycardia
    • Hyperthermia
    • Mydriasis (dilated pupils)
    • Agitation, seizures, psychosis
    • Chest pain from coronary vasospasm → MI
    • Arrhythmias, sudden death

Explanation of other options:

Heroin (Option A): An opioid that causes miosis, hypotension, and respiratory depression, not the sympathomimetic signs seen here.

Morphine (Option B): Another opioid with similar effects as heroin: miosis, bradycardia, hypotension, and CNS depression.

Chlorpheniramine (Option D): A first-generation antihistamine with sedating and anticholinergic effects (e.g., dry mouth, urinary retention), but not typically associated with hyperthermia and marked cardiovascular stimulation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents as calm and charming in front of a psychiatrist. However, he engages in aggressive behaviour towards friends, frequently skips classes, disregards traffic rules, and has been involved in a police interrogation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Persistent disregard for social rules, impulsivity, aggression, and lack of remorse strongly suggest Antisocial Personality Disorder.

  • Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) is a Cluster B personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others.
  • The diagnosis requires that this pattern has been present since age 15 (preceded by Conduct Disorder) and persists into adulthood.
  • Key Diagnostic Features of ASPD:
    • Frequent law-breaking, deceitful, and impulsive behaviour
    • Aggressiveness and irritability
    • Lack of remorse
    • Disregard for safety of self or others (e.g., skipping classes, breaking traffic rules)
    • Superficially charming or manipulative demeanor
  • These individuals often come into conflict with the law and are commonly involved in criminal investigations.
  • Treatment:
    • Psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), contingency management
    • Medications: Antipsychotics, mood stabilizers (e.g., lithium), β-blockers (for aggression)

Explanation of other options:

Narcissistic Personality Disorder (Option B): Characterized by grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy, but not commonly associated with aggression, criminal behaviour, or repeated rule-breaking.

Schizotypal Personality Disorder (Option C): Involves eccentric behaviour, odd beliefs, and social anxiety, but not aggression or legal troubles.

Paranoid Personality Disorder (Option D): Involves distrust and suspicion of others' motives without justification, not impulsivity or aggressive rule-breaking.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has consulted multiple plastic surgeons to correct a perceived facial deformity. Despite reassurances from doctors and her family that no such defect exists, she remains convinced and frequently checks her appearance in the mirror. She insists on surgical intervention. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

SSRIs are first-line pharmacological treatment for Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD), as they help reduce obsessional thoughts and compulsive behaviours related to perceived appearance flaws.

  • Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by:
    • Preoccupation with a perceived defect or flaw in appearance (often imagined or minor)
    • Repetitive behaviours such as mirror checking, excessive grooming, or seeking reassurance
    • Social withdrawal and impaired functioning
    • High rates of plastic surgery consultation, which often provides no relief
  • BDD falls under the Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders category in DSM-5.
  • Key Features:
    • Persistent thoughts about perceived physical flaws
    • Excessive comparisons with others
    • Poor insight or delusional conviction about their appearance
    • Functional impairment due to distress
  • Management:
    • First-line pharmacotherapy: SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, fluvoxamine)
    • First-line psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
    • Surgery is not recommended and usually leads to dissatisfaction

Explanation of other options:

Atypical antipsychotic (Option B): Used only in severe or delusional BDD or when there's poor response to SSRIs; not first-line.

Insight therapy (Option C): Insight-oriented psychotherapy is not effective in BDD, as most patients have poor or absent insight into their condition.

SNRI (Option D): SNRIs are less effective than SSRIs for obsessive-compulsive spectrum disorders like BDD and are not first-line.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4948290/

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic triad of hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and diffuse intracranial calcifications is the hallmark of congenital toxoplasmosis.

  • Congenital toxoplasmosis results from transplacental transmission of Toxoplasma gondii, particularly when maternal infection occurs during pregnancy.
  • The severity of fetal involvement depends on gestational age at the time of infection-early infection leads to more severe manifestations.
  • The classic triad includes:
    • Diffuse intracranial calcifications (often periventricular)
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Hydrocephalus
  • Other features may include:
    • Microcephaly
    • Seizures
    • Developmental delays
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Hearing loss
  • Diagnosis:
    • Prenatal: PCR from amniotic fluid, serial ultrasounds
    • Postnatal: Serology (IgM/IgA), CSF PCR, neuroimaging
  • Treatment:
    • Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Folinic acid for 1 year
    • Spiramycin for maternal infection in the 1st trimester

Explanation of other options:

Dandy-Walker Malformation (Option B): Characterized by posterior fossa cyst, agenesis of cerebellar vermis, and hydrocephalus-does not present with intracranial calcifications or chorioretinitis.

Budd-Chiari Syndrome (Option C): Caused by hepatic vein obstruction, presenting with hepatomegaly, ascites, and abdominal pain-no CNS findings like calcifications or hydrocephalus.

Congenital Hydrocephalus (Option D): Refers only to ventricular enlargement due to CSF accumulation. It does not account for chorioretinitis or intracranial calcifications, which point to a specific etiology like toxoplasmosis.
